q: What are the symptoms of cystitis?
a: Symptoms of cystitis include pain, burning or stinging when you pee, needing to pee more often and urgently than usual, pee that's dark, cloudy or strong smelling, and pain low down in your tummy.

q: When should I see a GP for cystitis?
a: You should see a GP if you think you have cystitis and your symptoms have not gone away within 3 days, your symptoms have not gone away after treatment with antibiotics, you have severe cystitis symptoms such as severe pain in your lower tummy, you get cystitis symptoms frequently, or if you are pregnant or a man and have symptoms of cystitis.

q: What should I do if I think someone has cystitis and shows symptoms of a kidney infection?
a: If you think someone has cystitis and shows symptoms of a kidney infection, such as a high temperature, pain in the lower tummy or back, confusion, or not having a pee all day, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: How does a GP treat cystitis?
a: A GP may offer self-care advice and recommend taking a painkiller for cystitis. They may also do a urine test, although this is not always needed. Depending on the situation, a GP may give you a prescription for a 3-day course of antibiotics, prescribe a single-dose antibiotic to take within 2 hours of having sex if sex triggers cystitis, or suggest a low-dose antibiotic for up to 6 months.

q: What are some self-help remedies for cystitis?
a: If you have mild symptoms of cystitis, you can try taking paracetamol to reduce pain, drinking plenty of water, avoiding drinks that may irritate your bladder, holding a hot water bottle over your lower tummy, and avoiding having sex. Some people also take cystitis sachets or cranberry drinks and products every day to prevent cystitis, although there is no evidence they help ease symptoms or treat an ongoing infection.

q: Can a pharmacist help with cystitis?
a: Yes, a pharmacist can help with cystitis. They can offer advice on treatments and self-care measures, suggest the best painkiller to take, and tell you if you need to see a GP about your symptoms. Some pharmacies even offer a cystitis management service and may be able to provide antibiotics if needed.

q: What are the common causes of cystitis?
a: Cystitis is usually caused by bacteria from fecal matter entering the urethra. Factors that increase the chances of bacteria reaching the bladder and causing infection include having sex, wiping your bottom from back to front after using the toilet, using urinary catheters, using spermicide with contraception, conditions that block the urinary tract, being pregnant, having difficulty emptying the bladder fully, having gone through menopause, having diabetes, or having a weakened immune system.

q: How can cystitis be prevented?
a: To help prevent cystitis from recurring, you can wipe from front to back when you go to the toilet, urinate as soon as possible after sex, drink plenty of fluids (especially water), have a shower instead of a bath, wash the skin around the vagina with water before and after sex, change soiled nappies or incontinence pads promptly, keep the genital area clean and dry, avoid using scented soap, bubble bath or talcum powder, avoid using spermicide with diaphragm or condoms, not hold your pee in if you feel the urge to go, not rush when urinating, avoid drinking excessive alcohol or coffee, and not consume large amounts of sugary foods or drinks. Taking D-mannose or cranberry products every day may also help prevent recurring cystitis in some cases.

q: Are there any additional ways to prevent cystitis?
a: In addition to the previous preventive measures, some people find it helpful to take D-mannose or cranberry products every day to prevent cystitis. However, it's important to note that D-mannose and cranberry products can contain a lot of sugar, and if you're taking warfarin, you should avoid cranberry products.

q: What are the symptoms of cystitis in young children?
a: Symptoms in young children may include a high temperature, wetting themselves, reduced appetite and being sick, and weakness and irritability.

q: When should I see a GP for cystitis?
a: You should see a GP if your cystitis symptoms haven't gone away within 3 days, if you have severe pain in your lower tummy, if you get cystitis frequently, or if you're pregnant or a man with symptoms of cystitis.

q: What should I do if I think I or someone else has cystitis?
a: If you think you or someone else has cystitis and you experience symptoms like a high temperature, pain in the lower tummy or back, or blood in your urine, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: What treatments can a GP provide for cystitis?
a: A GP may offer self-care advice, recommend painkillers, do a urine test, and prescribe either a 3-day course of antibiotics or antibiotics to be taken within 48 hours if symptoms don't go away. In recurrent cases, a single-dose antibiotic, low-dose antibiotics, or vaginal estrogen cream may be prescribed.

q: What can I do to relieve mild cystitis symptoms at home?
a: To relieve mild cystitis symptoms, you can take paracetamol, drink plenty of water, hold a hot water bottle over your lower tummy, avoid irritants like fruit juices and coffee, and try over-the-counter cystitis sachets or cranberry products.

q: Can a pharmacist help with cystitis?
a: Yes, a pharmacist can offer advice on treatments, recommend the best painkiller, and determine if a GP appointment is necessary. Some pharmacies also offer a cystitis management service and can provide antibiotics if needed.

q: What are the causes of cystitis?
a: Cystitis is usually caused by bacteria from the anus entering the urethra and reaching the bladder. Factors that increase the risk of bacteria entering the bladder include sexual activity, improper wiping after using the toilet, urinary catheters, spermicide use, urinary tract blockages, pregnancy, menopause, diabetes, and weakened immune systems.

q: How can cystitis be prevented?
a: To help prevent cystitis, it's recommended to wipe from front to back after using the toilet, urinate soon after sexual activity, drink plenty of fluids, avoid scented products, keep the genital area clean and dry, and avoid holding in urine or rushing when urinating. Supplements like D-mannose and cranberry products may also be helpful.

q: What are the symptoms of cystitis?
a: Symptoms of cystitis include pain, burning or stinging during urination, frequent and urgent need to urinate, dark or strong-smelling urine, and pain in the lower abdomen. In children, symptoms may also include high temperature, bedwetting, reduced appetite, and irritability. In older people, symptoms may include confusion, increased incontinence, and shivering or shaking.

q: When should I see a GP for cystitis?
a: You should see a GP if your cystitis symptoms have not gone away within 3 days, if your symptoms have not improved after treatment with antibiotics, if you have severe pain in your lower abdomen, if you frequently get cystitis symptoms, or if you are pregnant or male and experiencing cystitis symptoms. In urgent cases, such as having a high temperature, severe pain, or blood in your urine, seek immediate medical help.

q: How is cystitis treated by a GP?
a: A GP may offer self-care advice, recommend taking a painkiller, do a urine test, prescribe a 3-day course of antibiotics, or prescribe antibiotics but suggest waiting 48 hours before taking them. For recurring cystitis, a GP may prescribe a single-dose antibiotic for post-sex use, a low-dose antibiotic for up to 6 months, or a vaginal oestrogen cream for menopausal women.

q: What can I do to relieve mild symptoms of cystitis?
a: For mild symptoms of cystitis, you can try taking paracetamol up to 4 times a day, drinking plenty of water, using a hot water bottle on your lower abdomen, avoiding irritants like fruit juices and alcohol, and urinating frequently. However, if symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to consult a healthcare professional.

q: Can a pharmacist provide treatments for cystitis?
a: Yes, a pharmacist can provide advice on self-care measures and recommend painkillers. Some pharmacies may also offer a cystitis management service where antibiotics can be provided if necessary.

q: What are the possible causes of cystitis?
a: Cystitis is usually caused by bacteria from the anus entering the urethra and traveling to the bladder. Factors that increase the risk of developing cystitis include having sexual intercourse, wiping from back to front after using the toilet, using urinary catheters, using spermicide, having conditions that block the urinary tract, being pregnant, having difficulty emptying the bladder, having gone through menopause, having diabetes, or having a weakened immune system.

q: How can cystitis be prevented?
a: To help prevent cystitis, you can try wiping from front to back after using the toilet, urinating as soon as possible after sexual intercourse, staying hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids, opting for showers over baths, washing the genital area with water before and after sex, and maintaining good hygiene. Avoid using scented products, holding urine for too long, rushing when urinating, consuming excessive alcohol or coffee, and consuming sugary foods or drinks. Some evidence suggests that taking D-mannose or cranberry products regularly may help prevent recurrence.

q: Do D-mannose and cranberry products help prevent cystitis?
a: Taking D-mannose or cranberry products regularly may help prevent cystitis. D-mannose is a sugar that can be taken as a powder or tablets, while cranberry products are available as juice, tablets, or capsules. However, be cautious as these products can contain high amounts of sugar. If you take warfarin, it is advised to avoid cranberry products.

q: Are there any long-term risks associated with cystitis?
a: In some cases, chronic bladder infection, which is not picked up by usual urine tests, may be present. This condition is associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer in individuals aged 60 and over. If you have recurring cystitis symptoms that are unresponsive to treatment, ask your GP for a referral to a specialist for further evaluation and management.

q: What are the symptoms that require urgent medical attention in cystitis?
a: If you experience a high temperature, shaking or shivering, severe pain in the lower abdomen or back, confusion, nausea or vomiting, failure to urinate all day, or blood in the urine, it's important to seek urgent medical attention as these symptoms could indicate a kidney infection, which can be serious.
